III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Heartland Lansing is located in a two-story home with a basement. The six-bed
facility is located in Okemos, Michigan in a cul-de-sac area of a neighborhood.
Upon entering the front door to the home there is a stairway leading to the
upstairs of the home where the sleeping area is. To the right of the front doorway
2

area there is a living room that connects to the dining room and kitchen area. The
living room has furniture and a television. The dining room was observed to have
a table and chairs. To the right of the dining room is the kitchen which is observed
to have a working refrigerator, dishwasher, stove/oven, and sink. There are ample
cabinets and storage for kitchenware and food. Upon entering the front door,
there is a hallway which leads to be breakfast nook where there is another small
table area for sitting that is left of the kitchen. Left of the breakfast nook there is a
closed locked area where the laundry room is located. The laundry room has a
working washing machine, dryer and cleaning products. Next to the locked
laundry room area there is another open family room area with a couch and
television. Off this family room is a sunroom that has ample amount of natural
sunlight and leads to the fenced in backyard of the home. There is one bathroom
located on this level which is off the breakfast nook area and near the door to lead
to the basement of the home. There is a working toilet and sink within this
bathroom.
Upon entering the front door, to the left is a wooded spiral staircase that leads to
the upstairs of the home. The wooded spiral staircase has two handrails on each
side of the staircase and carpeted pads on each step for safety. At the top of the
staircase there is a hallway. To the right of the staircase there is a cut out nook
which is where staff will sit during overnight for supervision. Off this nook there is
a bathroom that has two sinks, a full bathtub and working toilet. To the right of the
nook there is one bedroom that has one bed that is 9’6” x 11’7” in size. To the
right of this bedroom is another room that will be office space for staff. Next to the
staff office there is one bedroom that has one bed that is 9’11” x 10’9” in size. To
the left of this bathroom there is another bathroom that has one working sink, one
working toilet, and a working shower. On the opposite side the upstairs that is left
to the staircase, there is one room that is 10’8”x11’7” that is the sensory area
room where there is a soft rug, a Nugget Play Couch, and other sensory items for
the youth to utilize. To the left of the sensory room is another staff office where the
clinical director’s office space will be. Across the hall from the sensory room are
two bedrooms that are 13’4”x10’9” and 13’9x10’9” in space. Each of these
bedrooms has two full size beds. The upstairs has a lot of natural light coming into
each of the rooms.
Within the basement area of the home there is a straight staircase that is near the
laundry room area on the main floor. Coming off the stairs there is a big recreation
room that is fully finished with carpeting, a couch and a television. This recreation
room is 28’5”x 23’11” and is a space for the youth to use. Off the recreation room
there are two locked door areas. One of the lock doors is a smaller room where
the locked medication cart is located and where other private information will be
kept that is locked up. The other locked door leads to a room where there are two
desks set up for the administration staff to utilize as their offices. The utility room
3

is located in a separate room that is only accessible through the office. The utility
room is where the working furnace and water heater is located.
An onsite walkthrough of the facility was completed on 06/09/2025.
The Fire Inspection was completed on 05/29/2025 stating Final Approval.
The Health Inspection was completed on 06/03/2025 and received A rating.
B. Program Description
Heartland Center for Autism is a for-profit corporation that provides a
comprehensive non-secure treatment program, for males and females, ages 6-17
years of age. The facility is being licensed for a capacity of six residents. The
program cares for residents who have mental health disorders, specifically
residents that have an autism spectrum disorder (ASD) diagnosis. Or other
closely related intellectual developmental disability. Referral sources for youth
may come from various sources and funders such as Community Mental Health
Organizations, Department of Health and Human Services, adoption subsides
(AGAO), private insurance and out of state Medicaid.
The facility will provide both a short-term program and treatment program. The
short-term program will be a 14-90 day stabilization program that will not exceed
90-day period of treatment. The treatment program will be up to 12 months
depending on the youth’s clinical presentation.
Both programs will deliver a treatment program that is in an environment where
youth will access reinforcement while targeting skill acquisitions and behavior
reduction goals during a time of crisis. During the time of admission, a Board-
Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) will review the youth’s skill set and deficits and
design a therapy program based on the principles and strategies of Applied
Behavior Analysis (ABA). The program’s primary therapy focus will be ABA
therapy, individual and group therapy, art, DBT, music, didactic, cognitive
behavior therapy are available and conducted as needed. The facility focuses on
a multidisciplinary trauma informed care approach to therapy which includes
medical, psychiatric, and therapeutic services in addition to 24/7 supervision and
care. Treatment planning will address the core deficits that youth with autism often
present such as Socializations, Communication, Adaptive Behavior, Daily Living
and Self-Help Skills. The program integrates families into treatment by including
parent/caregivers with clinical updates and training on a weekly basis when
deemed appropriate. Discharge planning begins on day one of admission.
Psychiatric services are contracted through a Board-Certified Child Psychiatrist
who provides care to all youth at Heartland Center for Autism. Medication reviews
will be conducted during the admission process and ongoing during treatment.
4

The facility will utilize the youths’ current medical/dental plan to ensure that all well
child/ dental exams and all medical needs are met. Educational services are
provided through the Okemos School District and are coordinated and overseen
by the facility’s case manager. The facility will collaborate with the full treatment
team of the youth to determine the best modalities for delivery of education (onsite
or remote).
The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:3 during waking hours and 1:6 during sleeping
hours. The facility will have no form of seclusions for the youth. Facility staff will
be trained in the use of MANDT System for de-escalation and emergency restraint
purposes. The MANDT System focuses on prevention of dysregulation in youth
and provides for the least restrictive therapeutic holds when there is an
emergency restraint needed.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The agency was found in compliance.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
original license be issued.
